_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:

Stationary Source and the Regulated substances Handled:

Multistar Industries, Inc. is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is the only Process Safety Management and Risk Management Planning regulated substance present at the Multistar Industries, Inc. Othello, Washington facility.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Multistar Industries, Inc. is committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  Our comprehensive accidental release prevention program, that covers areas such as the design, installation operating procedures and maintenance, demonstrates this commitment and the employee training associated with our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate control measures to prevent possible releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Unforeseeable, if such a release does occur, our highly trained personnel are available to mitigate the effects of the incident.  We are also completely coordinated with the Othello and Adams County 5 Fire Departments.

Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Case Release Scenario:

The Worst Case and Alternative Case release scenarios were developed using the methodologies provided in the EPA's RMP Comp and Marplot 5.1.1 software programs.  

The Worst Case Release Scenario involves the presumed rupture of the largest storage tank, a stationary railroad tank car containing 160,000 pounds of liquid anhydrous ammonia, due to a railroad switching accident where an inbound tank car is derailed and punctures the stationary tank car.

The Alternative Case Release Scenario involves the presumed failure of a transfer hose during the loading of a truck cargo tank.  The scenario assumes that when the transfer hose fails, the excess flow valve on the stationary railroad tank car temporarily freezes open, resulting in the loss of 2,000 pounds of liquid anhydrous ammonia.

Accidental Release Prevention and the Chemical-Specific

Prevention Program:

Multistar Industries, Inc. has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  In addition,, our facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Our facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the accidental release prevention program that is in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information:

Multistar Industries, Inc. currently maintains a detailed record of written process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design information associated with our anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution facility.
      
Process Hazard Analysis:

The methodology used to complete our Process Hazard Analyses is the What-If Checklist.  The Process Hazard Analyses are completed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are re-validated at an interval of at least every 5 years.  Any corrective actions noted from the hazard analyses are completed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:

Multistar Industries, Inc. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround.  The information is reviewed and approved at least annually by the Process Safety Management Committee.

Training:

Multistar Industries, Inc. has a training program in place to train employees who are operating and maintaining the storage and distribution equipment associated with the facility.  Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years to all personnel who operate and/or maintain the anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution system.    
 
Mechanical integrity:

Mu

ltistar Industries, Inc. conducts documented maintenance inspections and tests on process equipment to insure safe operation.  Process equipment examined by these inspections and tests include pressure vessels storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are performed by qualified personnel with the proper training and experience.  Any equipment deficiencies identified during maintenance inspections and tests are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change:

Written Management of Change procedures are in place at Multistar Industries, Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology equipment and procedures.  Equipment operators, maintenance personnel, and all other employees whose job tasks are affected by a change in a process, are promptly made aware of and provided training prior to implementing those changes.

Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews:

Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews related to new processes, and to modifications of existing processes, are conducted as a regular practice at Multistar Industries, Inc.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction equipment is designed and installed properly, and that operating and maintenance procedures and training are all complete prior to starting up new or modified ammonia storage and distribution equipment.

Compliance Audits:

Multistar Industries Inc. conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions required by the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Planning regulations are being implemented.  These audits are completed at least every 3 years and any corrective actions noted during the audits are completed in a safe and timely manner.

Incident Investigation:

Multistar Industries, Inc. promptly investigated all accidents and incidents that could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia.  These investigations are completed as soon as

possible after an accident or incident to identify the surface and root causes.  All reports generated by the accident/incident investigations are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation:

Multistar Industries, Inc. believes that process safety management and risk management planning compliance requires a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their concerns and recommendations regarding improving the safety and security of the ammonia storage and distribution equipment.  All employees have access to all information required by the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Plans.

Contractors:

Occasionally, Multistar Industries, Inc. retains contractors to conduct construction, maintenance or repair activities for the ammonia storage and distribution system.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of their training, certifications and experience is completed.  Multistar Industries, Inc. informs all visitors, vendors and contractors of all known and potential hazards regarding the ammonia storage and distribution equipment.  Emergency notification, evacuation and accountability procedures are reviewed with all contractors prior to them working on or near the ammonia storage and distribution system.

5-Year Accident History:

Multistar Industries, Inc. had no reportable accidents during the past 5 years.        

Emergency Action Plan:

Multistar Industries Inc. has a written Emergency Action Plan to protect site personnel and the public from accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  The plan includes all of the required components of emergency notification, evacuation and personnel accountability as well as first aid procedures and how the public is notified in the event of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Multistar Industries Inc. has implemented all of the corrective actions noted during the development and implementation of the Process S
afety Management and Risk Management Planning requirements.  In the future, we will continue our annual planning and training site visits with the Adams County Volunteer Fire Department personnel.
